title: TOC
description: The schema for table of contents (TOC) in Yaml or JSON format

name.description: A string name that is displayed for the TOC node. The name cannot include a colon (:).

displayName.description: An additional string value that doesnâ€™t get displayed (yes, it's a poor name) but is searched, as well as name, during TOC filtering.

href.description: The path the TOC node navigates to. Optional because nodes can exist just to parent other nodes. There are three-folded meanings for href: 1. href can specify the path the node navigates to. It can be either relative path, absolute path or external URL. 2. href can also point to another TOC file - this is the scenario called TOC include: all the items inside the included TOC file are considered and built into result as children of the current TOC node. 3. At last, href can point to a folder, indicating the navigation path be resolved to the first node in the TOC file under the root of that folder if both the TOC file and the node exist.

topicHref.description: Specifies the path the node navigates to (see #1 in href). It is useful when href points to another TOC file (see #2 in href) or points to a folder (see #3 in href), or tocHref is used.

tocHref.description: Specifies the TOC file to be included as children of the current node (see #2 in href), or specifies the folder path indicating the navigation path be resolved to the first node in the TOC file under the root of that folder (see #3 in href).

uid.description: The uid the TOC node navigates to. Optional because nodes can exist just to parent other nodes.

maintainContext.description: This property specifies whether the navigation to this TOC node maintains the current TOC context. The default value is false.

expanded.description: This property specifies whether the node should be expanded by default when the TOC is loaded. Only one root-level node can be expanded on load. The default value is false, so only add this with value true if you want the node to be expanded.

items.description: The tree which represents the hierarchy of the TOC.
